Posts.Content: Dec 12, 2009 11:18AM - edited Dec 12, 2009 11:19AM by chk8 Thank you, ladies, for all of your input.  I will see the oncologist on Tuesday for the official findings.  But, I had a pet scan this am and couldn't resist popping it in my computer when I got home.  I can see one lesion on my liver but not the 5 or 6 from last June.  I will take that as good news at least until I learn differently!  Sometimes it is a good thing to keep your head in the sand!  Sort of like denial... Connie

Posts.Content: May 24, 2010 07:08PM chk8 wrote: My employer provides short and long term disability coverage.  However, there is a pre-existing limitation if you have "consulted a physician 3 months prior to the most recent effective date of insurance."  I was already Stage IV when I began this job 2 years ago and have certainly seen my doctor for chemo every month in the last 2 years.  So, that seems to me that I won't be able to receive disability coverage for anything to do with breast cancer, right?  Any thoughts or experiences? Thanks!     Connie

Posts.Content: chk8 wrote: I just had a CT scan this morning.  They gave me a copy of my scan on a CD.  Of course, I went right home, put it in my computer, and with a few clicks I am looking at it!  Wow!  I've never seen a CT before but I can identify the basic anatomy in my abdomen and do not see any bright splotches.  Could this be good news?  I had liver lesions 6 months ago but have been on taxotere since then so maybe it is working!  I have other tests later in the week and will see the oncologist next Tuesday for the final word.  Does anyone else ever preview their scans? Posts.Content: chk8 wrote: I have had mets to my spine for over 6 years.  When first diagnosed and one more time when the AI's stopped working, back pain was one of the major clinical symptoms.  Although I have always called it back pain, it really is not in the center of my spine.   My pain has always been a little to the side.  Now, when I think I'm having another "crisis" (i.e. this chemo is not working), my pain is much more severe but still to the side (corresponds to my T8 and T10 lesions) and down my buttock and back of my thigh (corresponds to my L4 lesion).  Has anyone else expeience this kind of symptom? Thanks!   Connie Original dx Stage II 1989; local recurrence 1993; new occurrence in other breast 1994; mets to bones 2004; mets to liver 2007; ER+/PR+ Her2- Log in to post a reply

Posts.Title: Taxotere and watery eyes chk8 LRM216

Posts.Content: Oct 17, 2009 11:23AM chk8 wrote: Just to put my two cents worth in...I have been stage IV for 5 + years.  It started with several large lesions in my thoracic spine.  I had monthly arredia for several years to strengthen the bone, then was switched to zometa.  Those medicines worked very well and I have never had any fractures despite progression of the cancer in my bones.  I was also put on Femara, an AI,  when the stage IV was discovered and it worked for three years.  When the bony lesions increased and several spots appeared in my liver, I had 2 " mild" chemos in succession--xeloda and then doxil--which got rid of the liver spots and controlled the bony progression for nearly 2 years. Now, the liver spots have come back and the bone spots are spreading so I'm on taxotere.  The hope is still to "beat back" the cancer so I can go back on another AI.  But, in this last 5 years of ups and downs I have had good quality of life and have worked full time.  So, don't think of yourself as "terminal" but rather as having a chronic disease that you have to manage.
Posts.Title: Just diagnosed with liver metastasis Krystyna Krystyna

Posts.Title: army induction Leah_S DianaT

Posts.Content: Apr 2, 2010 06:09AM chk8 wrote: Jenny,  I feel for you right now, we've all been there.  It does get better.  I , too, am a healthcare professional (PT).  My limited history with oncology patients was very scary knowledge when I was first diagnosed with Stage IV disease, 6 years ago.  But remember, those oncology patients you saw in the hospital were most likely worst case scenarios.  I have been dealing with breast cancer for 20 years with Stage IV disease for the last 6 years.  I have never been in the hospital (except for the individual mastectomies) .  My Stage IV treatment was only a daily pill for the first 3 years (my cancer is ER+PR+).  Even now, on my 3rd consecutive chemo in the last 3 years, I work full time and have a pretty good quality of life.  So, please, take a deep breath, meet with your oncologist to get some plans set up, and visit us on this board the keep us informed! Connie

Has anyone experienced this?  I'd like to think it is dying cancer cells rather than further growing cancer cells.  Any thoughts? Posts.Content: Dec 18, 2009 06:49PM chk8 wrote: LC815, Thanks for the invite--I'm with you.  Hormonals worked for the first 3 years of my stage IV journey but I've been on chemo since October, 2007.  I am not in a study but the plan seems to be the same as yours--you take a chemo until it doesn't work any more or until you can't tolerate the side effects.  I got 1 year out of Xeloda, 9 months out of Doxil, and have been on Taxotere for 6 months.  I just went through the 6 month scans which were stable but my tumor markers have started creeping up for the last 2 months--usually the first sign that the chemo is beginning to lose its effectiveness.  Double crap!  Bald and tired for the rest of my life?! I really appreciate the support and understanding of the ladies on this site.  Remember, we are not alone (in our baldness and fatigue). Connie

Posts.Title: Spoke to Dr. Winer about next steps RobinWendy Reneepals

Posts.Content: Jan 22, 2010 02:06PM chk8 wrote: I have had bone mets for 6 years.  For the first 4 years, I was on monthly Aredia and then Zometa.  My understanding was that these medications were to strengthen the bones weakened by the cancer.  I did have progression in the bone mets during this time. After 4 years, the oncologist decreased the Zometa to once every 6 months.  He had always talked about the ONJ ("do you have any jaw pain" was a constant question) but I think he started to see more of it in his practice. The radiation oncologist was of the opinion that decreasing the frequency of the Zometa would allow the bony lesions to "spread out."  The medical oncologist did not agree.  In my opinion, effectiveness of the chemo or AI I receive has more influence on the bone mets than the Zometa.

Posts.Content: Oct 17, 2009 07:59PM chk8 wrote: My hair has thinned but not completely fallen out after 6 rounds of taxotere.  I, too, was amazed and discouraged by all of the gray fuzz.  So, I tried a "semi-permanent color"  (no peroxide or ammonia) and it has not  had any adverse effect on my fuzz.  Plus, it's more encouraging to see the golden fuzz than the gray fuzz.  Plus, since I wear a wig when I go out, this is the time to experiment with the color in preparation for some day when my regular hair grows back and I can get rid of the wig.  Plus, it's fun.

Posts.Content: Dec 7, 2009 10:04PM chk8 wrote: "I AM WOMAN, HEAR ME PEEP" I love your thought--it is so familiar.  I get aloxi with my taxotere and I think the aloxi causes constipation - it keeps things from coming up or going down!  I use the max dose of stool softeners beginning the day before the chemo and increase my intake of fluids, fiber, and fruit.  If nothing is happening after 3-4 days, I use Miralax.  I also take Prilosec daily for the nausea/heartburn sensation.  I hope you feel better soon.    (((Hugs))) from South Florida Connie

Glad you blood work looked good.

Posts.Content: Jun 20, 2009 11:00PM chk8 wrote: The waiting period is the worst!   I would reassure your mom that, IF this is a recurrence of her breast cancer, the treatment regimes of today are much improved as compared to the 1980's.  There are many new medications that control the disease and cause very little disruption in day to day life.  You just have to wait until the doctor's have all the information they need.  That is easier said than done--have been there many times in my 20 year history with this beast.
